metadata.title: Any other HR professionals out there? This is what the non-professional developer community looks like. | by Erica Usui | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Any other HR professionals out there? This is what the non-professional developer community looks like.
metadata.description: I have just started my Data Science journey and I can tell you this: I am not a natural and it is harder to learn as an adult. My motivation is the belief that by “doing” I will be able to understand…

all_paragraphs: I have just started my Data Science journey and I can tell you this: I am not a natural and it is harder to learn as an adult.

My motivation is the belief that by “doing” I will be able to understand and, hopefully, help to translate this new digital corporate world together with my colleagues of the profession — mainly HR professionals.

Recently I have been hearing a lot about how the most valuable capabilities in the future will be the ones that are fundamentally human. AI and automation will be present at our workplace doing tasks we thought only human intelligence was capable of.

This can sound like an argument to prioritize human sciences and emotional intelligence for the future of work. However, I think we still have many other building blocks to mold until we get there. It would be wise if we did not assume that functional knowledge and technical skill will simply be pushed into machines that will magically make things work automatically.

My view is: all professions (office workers, factory operators, sales clerks, teachers, CEOs…) need some level of digital literacy to learn how we can build this new reality in a way that we, as a society, don’t experience the daunting disruptive change we fear.

Our ability to test ideas and tell stories is much more effective when we do it with data. For some professionals, digital literacy in the future might come in the form of learning some programming skill to work with and make sense of complex and messy data sets.

In this post, I want to explore a snippet of this population using the 2019 Stack Overflow Annual Developer Survey. For those who are unfamiliar, Stack Overflow is the largest online community for developers to learn and share their programming knowledge.
What is the non-professional developers’ profile, job satisfaction and compensation? Let’s take a look…
I will refer to all the respondents who selected either one of these answers as “non-professional developers”.
Compared to 2017 survey data (11.78%), we can observe a small increase of this population participation.
These respondents are not professional developers, but how much coding experience do they have?
30 years old is the median age of the respondents. The median age at the first coding experience is 15 years old. However, the respondents have been coding for 8 years (median), so there is a gap.
What is their highest educational level and field of study?
64.18% of the population has at least a Bachelor’s degree.
The most common field of study is computer science/engineering (35.40%), followed by another engineering discipline (15.99%).
This population snippet is predominantly male (86%). Women represent 8% and other classifications, 6% of this population.
Here are the questions we will be looking into:
In order to give these qualitative answers a score, I did the following classification for “job satisfaction” and added the results:
Both the overall population and the non-professional developers have the same median score (3.00), however the average for the non-professional developers was lower (2.50 compared to 2.85).
In order to do a salary analysis, I selected the top ten countries with highest response frequency with compensation information:
There are some details we have to take into account when preparing salary information for visualization, for more details please check out my code here.

Let’s compare the compensation from respondents who are professional developers and from those who are not. For better visualization, the compensation was normalized into multiples of the country’s minimum wage and it was log-transformed.

The database contains a significant number of outliers, represented by the dots plotted above the maximum and below the minimum (probably dummy entries). We can perceive some differences on salary distribution comparing the countries:
It seems that comparing the two groups (professional developers and non-professional developers) the distributions are similar. Let’s take a look at the absolute information of the median.

It seems that this small non-professional developer community is comprised of a majority of people who had some exposure to coding during their formal education. Also, they code as part of their work.
As for job and career satisfaction, comparing this population to the overall respondents, there isn’t any significant discrepancy we could notice.

The same goes for the compensation distribution of non-professional developers and professional developers. We could observe some different behaviors between the countries, but, overall, not significant discrepancies between the professional and the non-professional developers.
These were only observational findings. I am very interested to see how this population will evolve through the years.
Will you join the digital transformation?
To see more about this analysis, see the link to my Github.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
A Brazilian living in Tokyo, learning to build new narratives.
